unnormalised: Gastroenterology, or as I like to call it, 'the tummy doc' field, deals with everything from your esophagus to your, well, the exit. It's a vast area, and honestly, quite fascinating! We're talking about conditions like acidity, which almost everyone in India experiences at some point after a spicy plate of biryani. Or more seriously, issues like IBD (Inflammatory Bowel Disease), which requires long-term mgmt and can really affect someone's quality of life. So, yeah, more than just tummy aches!

unnormalised: A lot of folks get confused about when they should actually see a gastroenterologist. Is it just for severe pain? What about bloating? The general rule of thumb is if you have persistent discomfort lasting for >2 weeks, or notice significant changes in your bowel habits (more frequent trips to the loo, or the opposite!), get it checked out. Dr. Sharma at AIIMS Delhi, for instance, is a renowned expert in the field, with 20+ years of experience. Don't self-medicate based on what you read on the internet!

unnormalised: One common complaint we see is GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease). You might know it as acid reflux or heartburn. It’s when stomach acid flows back into the esophagus, causing that burning sensation. Lifestyle changes, like avoiding spicy foods and eating smaller meals, can often help. Some patients even benefit from sleeping with their head elevated by 6 inches! However, if these don’t work, medications like PPIs (Proton Pump Inhibitors) are often prescribed.
normalised: One common complaint we see is G-E-R-D (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease). You might know it as acid reflux or heartburn. It’s when stomach acid flows back into the esophagus, causing that burning sensation. Lifestyle changes, like avoiding spicy foods and eating smaller meals, can often help. Some patients even benefit from sleeping with their head elevated by six inches! However, if these don’t work, medications like P-P-I-s (Proton Pump Inhibitors) are often prescribed.

unnormalised: Then there's the dreaded endoscopy. Yes, it involves a camera going down your throat or… elsewhere. But honestly, it's not as scary as it sounds. It allows doctors to visualize the lining of your digestive tract and identify problems like ulcers or polyps. The procedure itself usually takes <30 mins, and most people are sedated, so they don't feel a thing. It's a crucial diagnostic tool, esp for screening for conditions like colorectal cancer in individuals over 45 yrs.

unnormalised: Another important area is liver health. Conditions like fatty liver disease are becoming increasingly common due to our modern lifestyles. Early detection is key, as untreated fatty liver can lead to more serious problems like cirrhosis. Liver function tests, often done as part of a routine health checkup, can help identify potential issues. Consult your family physician if your SGPT levels are consistently >40 IU/L.

unnormalised: Ultimately, taking care of your gut health is crucial for your overall well-being. So, eat a balanced diet, stay hydrated, and listen to your body. And if something doesn't feel right, don't hesitate to seek expert advice. Remember, early detection and intervention can make all the difference! Take care, and have a happy tummy!
